author: bridge-bot
content: <pintolu> also watch out for third party libs. I remember the incident with ssh depending on commonly used compression lib: https://www.ssh.com/blog/a-recap-of-the-openssh-and-xz-liblzma-incident last year of centralized trust going wrong. It almost turned on remote shells everywhere. We do not know who manages these libs or who the maintainers are. We should hold Ethereum to gold standards

author: bridge-bot
content: <pintolu> no one's saying to write your own, but spread usage across commonly used (and audited) ones without picking one for everyone just because it's most performant by a tiny margin

author: bridge-bot
content:
<notnotstorm_p> re: **@pintolu**
> no one's saying to write your own, but spread usage across commonly used (and audited) ones without picking one for everyone just because it's most performant by a tiny margin
it's not really a tiny margin. that's what's difficult about this situation...all of these conventional rules of thumb make sense 99% of the time. but with large performance differences, and the fact that it's a cryptography lib, and the fact that it's very hairy low level code, all make the decision more complicated than just following conventional programming heuristics

but luckily we have a simple solution: just jack up the price of modexp until it's no longer the bottleneck for any client
